5.1 General.        Clauses have been described as composed of phrases (with
or without syntactic markers) and clause marginals ( 4 . 1 ) . The phrase
i s divided into phrase base and marginals ( 5 . 2 ) . The phrase and i t s
classes will be defined in t h i s chapter.
               Marginal s (both clause and phrase), syntactic markers (of word
and c l i t i c s t a t u s ) , i n t e r j e c t i o n s and the conjunction comprise those word
classes which do not function in the phrase base. These will be further
defined and described following the definitions of the phrase and phrase
classes.
5.2 Definitions of the Phrase and Phrase Classes. The phrase i s defined
by i t s place in the hierarchy as a unit higher than the word ( 2 . 4 ) and
lower than the clause ( 4 . I ) , functioning (with or without following syn-
t a c t i c markers) as an element of the clause, and composed of words and,
in certain cases, phrase o r clause constructs.
          The phrase i s divided into marginals and phrase base ( t h e re-
mainder), since these marginal s a r e potential outer components of phrases
of any class or type. They occur both preceding and following the phrase
base and thus delimit the boundaries of the phrase.
             On the basis of function in the clause, and in some cases,
occurrence with f o l l owing syntactic markers, the phrase may be divided
i n t o four classes : verbal, nominal , locative and adverbial. These wi 1 1
be defined here, b u t described both as t o function and s t r u c t u r e , in
chapters 7 t o 10.
5.2.1 The Verbal Phrase. The verbal phrase i s defined a s t h a t phrase
which functions only as the nucleus of the clause.
5.2.2 The Nominal Phrase. The nominal phrase i s defined as t h a t phrase
which may function as nucleus or sate1 1 i t e of the clause (4.1) and
which i s never followed by the locative syntactic marker (5.4.5).
5.2.3 The Locative Phrase. The locative phrase i s defined as t h a t phrase
which may function as nucleus o r s a t e l l i t e of the clause and which may be
followed by the locative syntactic marker.
5.2.4 The Adverbial Phrase. The adverbial phrase i s defined as that
phrase which functions only as a s a t e l l i t e of the clause.
5.3 Marginals. Plarginals may be defined as those words which occur as
outer components of the clause (4.2.2.5) or phrase, forming an IC with
one or other of these units. Their grammatical function i s thus t o
delimit a larger unit ( t h a t i s , the clause or phrase) in which they occur.
